greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Decimal expansion of exp(-LambertW(log(Pi))), solution to x = 1/Pi^x.
comment: Original definition: Limit of (1/Pi)^...^(1/Pi), n times, as n approaches infinity. Equals exp(-LambertW(log(Pi))).

The value can be obtained by iterating x -> 1/Pi^x with any real starting value, but convergence is linear and slow: about 5 iterations are needed for each additional decimal digit. - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 01 2011

According to the Weisstein link, infinite iterated exponentiation such as used here, which is referred to both as an "infinite power tower" and "h(x)" -- with graph and other notations -- "converges iff e^(-e) <= x <= e^(1/e) as shown by Euler (1783) and Eisenstein (1844)" (citing Le Lionnais and Wells references). e^(-e) = A073230. e^(1/e) = A073229. x of interest here = 1/Pi = A049541. (1/A073243)^(1/A073243) = A030437^A030437 = Pi.
If y = h(x) = x^x^x^... converges, then by substitution y = x^y. So x^x^x^... is a solution y to the equation y^(1/y) = x. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Aug 27 2011

The expressions involving "..." in the above comment are misleading, since the limit is not obtained by applying additional "^x" to the previous expression, i.e., iterating "t -> t^x", but corresponds to iterations of "t -> x^t". - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 01 2011
link: Stanislav Sykora, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1999
J. Sondow and D. Marques, Algebraic and transcendental solutions of some exponential equations, Annales Mathematicae et Informaticae 37 (2010) 151-164; see the Appendix.
formula: x = LambertW(log(Pi))/log(Pi), solution to Pi^x=1/x. - _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 01 2011
program: (PARI) /* The program below was run with precision set to 1000 digits */ /* n is the number of iterated exponentiations performed. */ /* (n turns out to be 954 with 1E-200 specified here) */ n=0; s=1/Pi; t=1; while(abs(t-s)>1E-200, t=s; s=(1/Pi)^s; n++); print(n,",",s)
xref: Cf. A000796 (Pi), A049541 (1/Pi), A073240 ((1/Pi)^(1/Pi)), A073241 ((1/Pi)^(1/Pi)^(1/Pi)), A030437 (reciprocal of A073243), A030178 (corresponding limit for 1/e), A030797 (reciprocal of A030178).
results.author: _Rick L. Shepherd_, Jul 28 2002
